subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Way/Why
msgSnippet: ... Oh, I agree.  Moving from improve to improove only requires a period of adjustment.  But what I am arguing against is a situation in which it is
messageBody:
Paige Gabhart scripsit:

> Furthermore, once one has seen an atypical, but more accurate
> spelling a few times, it would start to look familiar and stop
> slowing the reader down.

Oh, I agree. Moving from "improve" to "improove" only requires a period
of adjustment. But what I am arguing against is a situation in which
it is thought just as acceptable to write "Shaxpers" as "Shakespeare".
Having a good spelling for a word is much better than having a bad
spelling, but having one bad spelling is better than having two, and
having two spellings is better than having thirty.

> A Wikipedia article states that 17% of the U.S. public still
> distinguishes "wh" from "w" to some extent. If this is correct,
> that represents roughly 50-55 million people (not even counting the
> Irish and Scottish), which is close to the population of England. I
> hardly find that "relatively few people." I would also note that
> Read decided to include the sound in QS after ignoring it in
> Shavian.

Fair points.

--
You are a child of the universe no less John Cowan
than the trees and all other acyclic http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
graphs; you have a right to be here. cowan@...
--DeXiderata by Sean McGrath

Oh, I agree.  Moving from "improve" to "improove" only requires a period

Having a good spelling for a word is much better than having a bad

> A Wikipedia article states that 17% of the U.S. public still
